docs.lead_paragraph: Inspired by new findings on the way animal brains develop before and after birth, scientists are developing provocative new theories to explain autism, a mysterious brain abnormality that prevents human infants from developing normal social and cognitive skills. By studying the anatomy of autistic brains, researchers are trying to figure out when in development and where in the brain the complex interaction of genes and environment causes things to go astray. In the process, they are learning more about the brain circuitry that gives rise to quintessential human traits like language, empathy and the awareness that other people have beliefs and desires different from one's own.

headline.main: New Theories Help Explain Mysteries of Autism

docs.abstract: Scientists are developing provocative new theories to explain autism, inspired by new findings on the way animal brains develop before and after birth; hope to determine when in development and where in the brain the complex interaction of genes and environment causes things to go astray; are learning more about brain circuitry that gives rise to human traits like language, empathy and awareness that other people have beliefs and desires different from one's own; concede that it will take many years to understand genetics and neurochemistry of autism; believes intensive one-on-one treatment of autistic children should begin by age 2 or 3; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Inspired by new findings on the way animal brains develop before and after birth, scientists are developing provocative new theories to explain autism, a mysterious brain abnormality that prevents human infants from developing normal social and...

docs.lead_paragraph: IT was a match made in hell: she with the cool gaze and the silky long legs, he with the rhythm-and-blues soul and that incessant smirk. And from the moment Bruce Willis called Cybill Shepherd a rude five-letter name and she returned the compliment with a quick hand across his face, viewers were smitten by the bickering sweethearts and their television love nest, ''Moonlighting.'' Fifteen years later, their chemistry seems as potent as ever. Which is exactly what Bravo was banking on when it acquired 65 episodes of the ABC series and anointed them ''TV too good for TV,'' an honor already bestowed on 1980's classics like ''Max Headroom'' and ''Brooklyn Bridge.'' Next Sunday at 1 p.m., Bravo will introduce its newest addition with a mini-marathon of the first seven episodes before adding ''Moonlighting'' to its weeknight lineup at 7 p.m., beginning the next day.
docs.abstract: Success of 1980's television series Moonlighting recalled in light of Bravo plan to air reruns; photo (M)
docs.snippet: IT was a match made in hell: she with the cool gaze and the silky long legs, he with the rhythm-and-blues soul and that incessant smirk. And from the moment Bruce Willis called Cybill Shepherd a rude five-letter name and she returned the compliment...

docs.lead_paragraph: JOSHUA KANNER of Merrick was already sitting on the examining table when Sam Benjamin arrived, hugged his 5-year-old patient, asked Joshua's mother, Gail, about her son's progress since their last visit, and then carefully inserted several fine needles into the boy's hands and legs. Joshua has cerebral palsy, and the acupuncture treatment was intended to correct an imbalance in his chi, his energy system.

headline.main: At Stony Brook, Study of Alternative Medicine Faces Skeptics

docs.abstract: Center for Complementary and Alternative Medicine, State University of New York at Stony Brook's controversial attempt to use and research treatments like acupuncture and herbology in an academic setting, celebrates its second annivesary; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Say hello to Lucy Jane Wasserstein. Mother: Pulitzer-prize winning playwright, Wendy Wasserstein. Father: not yet announced. Born: Sept. 12, 1999, in Mount Sinai Hospital, New York. Weight: 790 grams, under 2 lbs. And what a production it was! The director Gerald Gutierrez (''The Heiress,'' ''A Delicate Balance'') was in the delivery room. The costume designer William Ivey Long (''Crazy for You,'' ''Chicago,'' ''Guys and Dolls'') decorated the hospital room. Meryl Streep, Ms. Wasserstein's friend from the Yale Drama School, sneaked in to see the baby, incognito. The writer James Lapine (''Passion,'' ''Sunday in the Park With George'') and the set designer Heidi Ettinger (''Big River,'' ''The Secret Garden'') brought mother and baby home.

headline.main: The Newest Wasserstein Creation Comes Home

docs.abstract: Wendy Wasserstein, Pulitzer-prize winning playwright, gave birth to baby girl two months prematurely and was able to bring her home just before Thanksgiving; will not say how she got pregnant or by whom; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Abortion Is Rejected for a Girl, 13, Bitterly Dividing the Italians'' (news article, Dec. 17): The circumstances related to a developmentally disabled girl's pregnancy demonstrate the denial and shame surrounding sexual activity and the disabled.
docs.abstract: Mindy Roseman letter on case of 13-year-old mentally retarded pregnant girl in Italy who was denied right to have abortion; holds people with disabilities have same human and reproductive rights as everyone else
